facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 150 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCiVil Appeal No. 150 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated March 22, 1960, of the Assam High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 7 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 22, 1960, of the Assam High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 7 of 1959.

facts.text: By a registered lease deed dated March 31, 1950, the assessee-company leased out two tea estates named Panbari Tea Estate and Barchola Tea Estate.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered lease deed dated March 31, 1950, the assessee-company, respondent herein, leased out two tea estates named Panbari Tea Estate and Barchola Tea Estate, along with machinery and buildings owned and held by it, in Darrang, in the State of Assam, to a firm named Messrs. Hiralal Ramdas for a period of ten years companymencing from January 1, 1950.

facts.text: Lease was for Panbari Tea Estate and Barchola Tea Estate along with machinery and buildings in Darrang, Assam.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered lease deed dated March 31, 1950, the assessee-company, respondent herein, leased out two tea estates named Panbari Tea Estate and Barchola Tea Estate, along with machinery and buildings owned and held by it, in Darrang, in the State of Assam, to a firm named Messrs. Hiralal Ramdas for a period of ten years companymencing from January 1, 1950.

facts.text: Lease was to Messrs. Hiralal Ramdas for a period of ten years commencing from January 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered lease deed dated March 31, 1950, the assessee-company, respondent herein, leased out two tea estates named Panbari Tea Estate and Barchola Tea Estate, along with machinery and buildings owned and held by it, in Darrang, in the State of Assam, to a firm named Messrs. Hiralal Ramdas for a period of ten years companymencing from January 1, 1950.

facts.text: Lease consideration: premium of Rs. 2,25,000/- and annual rent of Rs. 54,000/-

anchor.surface_text: The lease was executed in companysideration of a sum of Rs. 2,25,000/as and by way of premium and an annual rent of Rs. 54,000/- to be paid by the lessee to the lessor.

facts.text: Premium Rs. 45,000/- paid in one lump sum at execution, balance Rs. 1,80,000/- in 16 half yearly instalments of Rs. 11,250/- on or before January 31 and July 31 each year.

anchor.surface_text: The premium was made payable as follows Rs. 45,000/- to be paid in one lump sum at the time of the execution of the lease deed and the balance of Rs. 1,80,000/in 16 half yearly instalments of Rs. 11,250/- on or before January 31 and July 31 of each year.

facts.text: Annual rent Rs. 54,000/- payable Rs. 1,000/- per month on or before last day of each month (Rs. 12,000/- year) and balance Rs. 42,000/- on or before December 31 each year.

anchor.surface_text: The annual rent of Rs. 54,000/- was payable as follows Rs. 1,000/- per month to be paid on or before the last day of each month, making in all Rs. 12,000/- per year, and the balance of Rs. 42,000/- on or before December 31 of each year.

facts.text: On February 25, 1957, Income-tax Officer made assessment for 1952-53 treating instalment of Rs. 11,250/- as revenue receipt.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1957, for the assessment year 1952-53, the Income-tax Officer made the assessment treating the instalment of Rs. 11,250/- paid towards the premium in the relevant accounting year as a revenue receipt of the assessee.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held premium was rent chargeable to income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal also held that the premium was really the rent payable under the lease deed and, therefore, it was chargeable to income-tax.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court under s.66(1) of Income-tax Act, 1922: Whether Rs. 11,250/- received is revenue or capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee, the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, herein after called the Act Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case and upon the companystruction of the terms of the lease, dated 31st March 1950, the sum of Rs. 11,250/- received by the assessee during the year of account is revenue or capital receipt.

facts.text: Assam High Court held Rs. 11,250/- was capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the said sum of Rs. 11,250/- received by the assessee during the year of account was a capital receipt and answered the question accordingly.

facts.text: Appeal filed in Supreme Court on certificate issued by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On a certificate issued by the High Court, this appeal has been filed by the Revenue in his Court.

facts.text: Tea estates comprise 320 acres and 305 acres respectively under tea, along with bungalows, factory buildings, etc.

issues.text: whether the amount described as premium in the lease deed is really rent and, therefore, a revenue receipt.

anchor.surface_text: On a certificate issued by the High Court, this appeal has been filed by the Revenue in his Court. The short question that arises in this appeal is whether the amount described as premium in the lease deed is really rent and,

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1957, for the assessment year 1952-53, the Income-tax Officer made the assessment treating the instalment of Rs. 11,250/- paid towards the premium in the relevant accounting year as a revenue receipt of the assessee.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court correctly held it as capital receipt; no material to displace description as premium.

arguments.claim: The premium was really the rent payable under the lease deed and therefore chargeable to income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal also held that the premium was really the rent payable under the lease deed and, therefore, it was chargeable to income-tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s premium and to hold that they are number in fact premium but only rent. Indeed, the circumstances mentioned supra companyfirm the said description.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court correctly answered as capital receipt; lease terms show distinct premium.

arguments.claim: Clause 8 treats instalments of premium and annual rent similarly; upon default and re-entry, lessor entitled only to balance instalment of unpaid premium or rent, indicating premium is rent.

arguments.claim: The sum of Rs. 11,250/- received by the assessee during the year of account was a capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the said sum of Rs. 11,250/- received by the assessee during the year of account was a capital receipt and answered the question accordingly.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s premium and to hold that they are number in fact premium but only rent. Indeed, the circumstances mentioned supra companyfirm the said description.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court gave correct answer to the question.

arguments.claim: Salami/premium is a single payment (or instalments) for acquisition of right to enjoy benefits of lease, a capital asset.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between premium and rent was brought out by the Judicial Committee in Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh of Ramgarh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa  1  thus It  salami  is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessee to enjoy the benefits granted to them by the lease.

arguments.claim: Indicia of salami: single non-recurring character and payment prior to creation of tenancy; consideration for being let into possession; capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Member for the Board of Agriculture Income-tax, Assam v. Sindhurani Chaudhurani  2  defined salami as follows The indicia of salami are  1  its single non-recurring character and  2  payment prior to the creation of the tenancy.

arguments.claim: Real test for salami/premium: whether amount paid in lump sum or instalments is consideration for being let into possession.

anchor.surface_text: The real test is whether the said amount paid in a lump sum or in instalments is the consideration paid by the tenant for being let into possession.

arguments.claim: Under s.105 TPA, lease involves premium (price for transfer of right to enjoy) distinct from rent (periodical payments); former capital, latter revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 105 of the Transfer of Property Act, a lease of immovable property is a transfer of a right to enjoy the property made for a certain time, express or implied or in perpetuity, in consideration of a price paid or promised,... The section, therefore, brings out the distinction between a price paid for a transfer of a right to enjoy the property and the rent to be paid periodically to the lessor.

arguments.claim: Substance of transaction matters over form or nomenclature; but nomenclature helps ascertain intention.

anchor.surface_text: There may be circumstances where the parties may camouflage the real nature of transaction by using clever phraseology. In some cases, the so-called premium is in fact advance rent and in others rent is deferred price. It is not the form but the substance of the transaction that matters.

arguments.claim: Lease transfers substantive interest for 10 years; premium Rs.2,25,000 for transfer of right, distinct from annual rent Rs.54,000 for use; parties businessmen knew difference; no camouflage.

anchor.surface_text: Under that document interest in two large tea estates comprising 320 acres and 305 acres respectively under tea, along with the bungalows, factory buildings, houses, godowns, cooly lines and other erections and structures, was parted by the lessor to the lessee for a period of 10 years... Under cl. 4 of the lease deed for the transfer of the right a premium of Rs. 2,25,000/- had to be paid to the lessor and for using the estates the lessee had to pay an annual rent of Rs. 54,000/-.

arguments.claim: The amount described as premium is capital receipt, not rent; High Court correct.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the High Court has given a correct answer to the question submitted to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

holdings.text: the sum of Rs. 11,250/- received by the assessee during the year of account is a capital receipt

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the High Court has given a correct answer to the question submitted to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease deed describes distinct premium for transfer of right to enjoy estates and rent for use; parties businessmen knew difference; instalments accommodate lessee; precedents on salami/premium as capital apply; cl.8 default clause saves rights without altering nature; profit figures show higher return post-lease, no material displaces description.

holdings.text: Under s. 105 of the Transfer of Property Act, premium is price paid for transfer of right to enjoy property (capital receipt) distinct from rent paid periodically for continuous enjoyment (revenue receipt)

anchor.surface_text: The section, therefore, brings out the distinction between a price paid for a transfer of a right to enjoy the property and the rent to be paid periodically to the lessor. When the interest of the lessor is parted with for a price, the price paid is premium or salami. But the periodical payments made for the continuous enjoyment of the benefits under the lease are in the nature of rent. The former is a capital income and the latter a revenue receipt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of s.105 TPA defines lease components; aligns with judicial precedents distinguishing salami/premium from rent.

holdings.text: The real test whether amount paid in lump sum or instalments is premium/salami (capital) is if it is consideration for tenant being let into possession

anchor.surface_text: The real test is whether the said amount paid in a lump sum or in instalments is the consideration paid by the tenant for being let into possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopted from Supreme Court precedent in Sindhurani Chaudhurani; applies to instalment payments; confirmed in Chintamani case for short-term rights.

holdings.text: Clause 8 of lease deed does not indicate premium is rent; default clause saves right to recover instalments without depriving other rights or overriding main terms distinguishing premium and rent

anchor.surface_text: Nor is cl. 8 of the lease deed, on which strong reliance is placed by the learned counsel for the Revenue, a pointer to the contrary. ... The drafting of the clause is not artistic and is rather confused but in the context of the other clauses it cannot be so construed as to override or come into conflict with, the main terms of the lease deed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.8 provides re-entry option without prejudice to rights including recovery of unpaid instalments; cannot destroy main consideration clause describing premium distinctly; harmonious construction with cl.1 and cl.4.

holdings.text: No material in profit figures before/after lease displaces description of premium as capital; post-lease total returns higher than pre-lease net profits

anchor.surface_text: A comparative study of the said figures discloses a higher return in the second period than during the earlier period. ... In the absence of the relevant material it is not possible to accept the argument built upon the said figures.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adjusted figures show higher income post-lease; no agreed data for further adjustments; cannot infer split rent without evidence.

holdings.text: Parties did not camouflage rent as premium; businessmen knew distinction between premium for transfer of right (Rs.2,25,000 spread Rs.22,500/year) and substantial annual rent (Rs.54,000); instalments not decisive

anchor.surface_text: Under cl. 4 of the lease deed for the transfer of the right a premium of Rs. 2,25,000/- had to be paid to the lessor and for using the estates the lessee had to pay an annual rent of Rs. 54,000/-. ... There is no reason, therefore, to assume that the parties camouflaged their real intention and fixed a part of the rent in the shape of premium.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantive interest transferred for 10 years; nomenclature helps ascertain intention; no evidence of ulterior motive; substance matches form.

precedents.citation: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh of Ramgarh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between premium and rent was brought out by the Judicial Committee in Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh of Ramgarh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 1 thus It salami is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessee to enjoy the benefits granted to them by the lease. That general right may properly be regarded as a capital asset, and the money paid to purchase it may properly be held to be a payment on capital account.

precedents.case_name: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh of Ramgarh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between salami (capital payment for right to enjoy lease benefits) and royalties (revenue)
precedents.cited_holding: salami is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessee to enjoy the benefits granted to them by the lease. That general right may properly be regarded as a capital asset, and the money paid to purchase it may properly be held to be a payment on capital account. But the royalties are on a different footing

precedents.citation: Member for the Board of Agriculture Income-tax, Assam v. Sindhurani Chaudhurani 2

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Member for the Board of Agriculture Income-tax, Assam v. Sindhurani Chaudhurani 2 defined salami as follows The indicia of salami are 1 its single non-recurring character and 2 payment prior to the creation of the tenancy. It is the consideration paid by the tenant for being let into possession and can be neither rent nor revenue but is a capital receipt in the hands of the landlord.

precedents.case_name: Member for the Board of Agriculture Income-tax, Assam v. Sindhurani Chaudhurani
precedents.cited_proposition: Salami is single non-recurring payment prior to tenancy for being let into possession; capital receipt; can be paid in lump sum or instalments; test is whether consideration for possession
precedents.cited_holding: The indicia of salami are 1 its single non-recurring character and 2 payment prior to the creation of the tenancy. It is the consideration paid by the tenant for being let into possession and can be neither rent nor revenue but is a capital receipt in the hands of the landlord.

precedents.citation: Chintamani Saran Nath Sah Deo v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court again in Chintamani Saran Nath Sah Deo v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 1 considered all the relevant decisions on the subject in the context of licences granted to the assessee to prospect for bauxite in some cases for 6 months and in others for a year or two and observed The definition of salami was a general one

precedents.case_name: Chintamani Saran Nath Sah Deo v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Salami definition applies to licences granting right to prospect; grant of right to portion of capital asset is capital receipt
precedents.cited_holding: under the said licences there was a grant of a right to a portion of the capital of the licensor in the shape of a general right to the capital asset

anchor.surface_text: The section, therefore, brings out the distinction between a price paid for a transfer of a right to enjoy the property and the rent to be paid periodically to the lessor. When the interest of the lessor is parted with for a price, the price paid is premium or salami. But the periodical payments made for the continuous enjoyment of the benefits under the lease are in the nature of rent. The former is a capital income and the latter a revenue receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Under cl. 4 of the lease deed for the transfer of the right a premium of Rs. 2,25,000/- had to be paid to the lessor and for using the estates the lessee had to pay an annual rent of Rs. 54,000/-. ...
